item.title: Brussels Placed at Highest Alert Level; Subway Is Closed
item.description: Prime Minister Charles Michel said raising the alert meant that the threat was “serious and imminent.”
item.dc:creator: MILAN SCHREUER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Belgian soldiers patrolled a nearly deserted street on Saturday in central Brussels, after the government raised the country’s threat level to its highest.

item.title: State of Terror: ISIS Wives and Enforcers in Syria Recount Collaboration, Anguish and Escape
item.description: Three young women who fled to southern Turkey recalled their experiences under Islamic State rule and how the jihadists utterly changed life in Raqqa, Syria.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: AZADEH MOAVENI
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Aws, 25, a former resident of Raqqa, Syria, used to be a member of the Khansaa Brigade, the Islamic State's female morality police. Her first husband was a jihadist, and when he died in a suicide operation she reluctantly agreed to marry another fighter.

item.title: Refugees Must Not Be Turned Away, Obama Says
item.description: President Obama, speaking in Malaysia, said the United States should not close itself to the world’s refugees out of fear as he met with children who have fled violence.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL D. SHEAR
item.media:description: President Obama visited a center for child refugees on Saturday in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. He said such children should not be barred from entering the United States over security fears.

item.title: 3 Chinese Executives Killed in Mali Attack, Company Says
item.description: The China Railway Construction Corporation said the three men were killed by gunmen at the start of the hotel siege on Friday.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: For Woman Dead in French Police Raid, Unlikely Path to Terror
item.description: Hasna Aitboulahcen once liked to drink, smoke and stay out late. She spent her last days in a St.-Denis hide-out for Islamist militants.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: An apartment building in the Paris suburb of St.-Denis a day after a raid by the French police.

item.title: U.S. Victim of Mali Attack Worked on Women’s Health
item.description: Anita Ashok Datar, an American who was killed in the Mali attack, was devoted to her young son and to helping women in poverty around the world.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: World Briefing: 9 North Koreans Feared Deported
item.description: The United Nations expressed alarm about the fate of North Koreans feared to have been deported from Vietnam via China back to their homeland.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Lithuania: Misfires at AK-47’s Debut
item.description: Arming police officers with AK-47s led to an accidental shooting and the theft of a weapon — and to the resignation of the interior minister,
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Italy: 6 Arrested in Plot Against Official
item.description: The police arrested members of Sicily’s Cosa Nostra as part of an inquiry that uncovered a threat of violence against Interior Minister Angelino Alfano.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Paris Attacks Force European Union to Act on Border Controls
item.description: Officials met in an emergency session and vowed to complete French proposals for tighter controls by the end of the year.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Bonfires in Gevgelija, Macedonia, helped migrants stay warm on Friday as they waited to enter a registration camp after crossing the border from Greece.

item.title: Migrants’ Attempts to Enter U.S. via Mexico Stoke Fears About Jihadists
item.description: Federal officials said the migrants — from Syria, Pakistan and Afghanistan — appeared to have no radical intentions, but the episodes added to concerns after the Paris attacks.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: RICHARD PÉREZ-PEÑA

item.title: Paris and Mali Attacks Expose Lethal Qaeda-ISIS Rivalry
item.description: The competition between the two groups, first provoked by differing strategies in Syria, will be hard to stamp out even if armies can weaken the jihadists in the Middle East and Africa.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: News Analysis: Groups Claiming Responsibility in Mali Attack Have History of Resilience
item.description: Al Mourabitoun and Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb have complicated histories but maintain ties to Al Qaeda and nomadic tribesmen.
item.category: Al Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Syrian Family Diverted From Indiana Feels ‘Welcomed’ in Connecticut
item.description: A family of three from Homs, Syria, arrived to Kennedy International Airport on Tuesday amid a political backlash.
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.dc:creator: LIZ ROBBINS
item.media:credit: Christopher Capozziello for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kate Wood, a case worker at I.R.I.S. in New Haven, in her office this month. She helps Syrian refugees find temporary housing.

item.title: Jonathan Pollard, American Who Spied for Israel, Released After 30 Years
item.description: The American convicted of spying for Israel was released on parole on Friday, but the Obama administration had no plans to let him move to Israel.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: A rally in Jerusalem in 2005 in support of Jonathan J. Pollard.

item.title: Americans View Paris Attacks With Empathy, Fear and Resolve
item.description: In interviews around the country, many Americans were sorry about what had happened and fearful of attacks at home.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: JACK HEALY and RICHARD FAUSSET
item.media:description: The Los Angeles City Hall was lighted in the colors of the French flag on Tuesday night.

item.title: Argentina Considers Shift as Upstart Rises in Presidential Race
item.description: With Mauricio Macri leading in polls for Argentina’s election on Sunday, many in the country are gauging the impact of a shift away from Peronist policies.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and JONATHAN GILBERT
item.media:description: Mauricio Macri was given a poncho as he campaigned for the presidency on Thursday in Humahuaca, Argentina.

item.title: U.N. Security Council Approves Resolution Urging Countries to Combat Islamic State
item.description: The resolution, approved in a 15-to-0 vote, called on countries around the world to take “all necessary measures” to fight the jihadist group.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA
item.media:description: The French ambassador, François Delattre, before the Security Council's vote on Friday.

item.title: Russian Newspaper’s Scoop? Based on Fake Letters, U.S. Says
item.description: The State Department told the newspaper Izvestia that letters supposedly proving that Russian gay rights activists were traitors were obviously faked.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.media:description: Police officers in Moscow detained Nikolai A. Alekseyev, a Russian gay rights activist, during a demonstration in May.

item.title: Open Source: A Dutch ISIS Fighter Is Taking Questions on Tumblr
item.description: Israfil Yilmaz, who abandoned a career in the Royal Netherlands Army to join Islamist rebels, replied with personal, technical and theological answers.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A question and answer posted on Friday on an Islamic State militant’s blog.
